ygData.subject: Re: [neat] "Survive and Reproduce" as an Objective
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Ken, ... I m not sure I agree with the spirit of your argument but it s just a gut feeling at this point so I ll have a go at clarifying my thoughts a bit

Subject: Re: [neat] "Survive and Reproduce" as an Objective
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=344770077; y=QIR0rXYVHpwBpZyv9wE3arJKOq_jsox-3ob2IzQus3EpoUiDeWfv

Hi Ken,


On 4 April 2011 21:40, Ken <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Colin, I wanted to branch my response to you to a new thread because I want to focus
> on the idea that "survive and reproduce" is an objective. This is not really an argument
> with anything you said, but mainly a commentary on the meaning of "objective" that I
> think draws a useful distinction.

I'm not sure I agree with the spirit of your argument but it's just a
gut feeling at this point so I'll have a go at clarifying my thoughts
a bit further and maybe I can home in a bit more on where I'm
disagreeing (if at all).

By 'survive' I mean - execute some strategy that results in survival.
So find food and shelter, avoid danger, etc. Good survival strategy
for the domain => good chance of surviving, bad strategy => lower
chance.

In an EA that survival *strategy* is 'do well on the fitness metric'
(aka objective) - because the only way to survive is to get selected
by the EA's selection criteria. So I think we can clarify the argument
by drawing a distinction between surviving/reproducing and
/strategies/ that lead to surviving and reproducing. I think perhaps
we (or I) have conflated the two. Survive/reproduce is the high level
[implicit] objective that is always present, and survival /strategy/
is what we normally refer to as objective or goal in EC.

So far there's no distinction between nature/biology and EC. To my
mind nature has found complex /strategies/ for survival because:

A) Vastly more computational resource (or equivalent) [per unit time].
B) Vastly more time.
C) Vastly more complex domain.

It's this latter point that I feel has tended to be overlooked. If you
consider every living thing alive today and trace back through all of
their ancestors, then every single one of those zillions of organisms
executed a successful strategy that lead to survival. Considerably
more organisms not on that family tree didn't survive - so the natural
world does try out unsuccessful strategies, but only for one
generation at a time, it doesn't create offspring with variations on
those poor strategies in the hope of finding something better. What
does happen though is that stragies are so complex (for creatures with
large brains anyway) that they can incorporate successful parts (find
food) and yet waste much time on poor sub-strategies (effectively
stragey efficiency). Evolution will select for efficiency but unlike
survival it's not a binary yes/no thing, it's more probabilistic, so
more like the small low scoring species in NEAT (from fitness
sharing).

It's perhaps those poor side strategies that fit your idea of
searching with no objective, they piggy back on for the ride and very
occasionally become useful. Where EC tends to fall short IMO is that
the domain complexity is vastly lower than the natural world so
there's less opportunty for exploring variations in strategy -
branching off into multiple successful branches and sub-branches
without a major loss in fitness on the objective. Put another way, the
natural world's fitness landscape is dominated by smooth undulations
in all dimensions, whereas EC objectives tend to have a few
sharp/steep local maxima.

Nature also provides a gentle selection pressure towards complex
strategies by providing resources that require increasingly complex
strategies to reach - you can't eat those land plants until you evolve
legs ang lungs. And you can't eat those omnivores without evolving
good eyes and fast/strong muscles, etc. but the plants and meat were
there as an untapped resource until that first legged creature and
first carnivore came along. So we can see now that framing the
survival as being an objective that's been achieved on day one misses
a lot of the key dynamics that drive evolution. Surviving is the high
level implicit objective, some species have not moved on from floating
in the sea eatign CO2 and sunlight, but other strategies were evolved
to tap into new previously untapped resources - and that climb from
simple to complex resources utilisation continues to this day.

Colin.
